item.title: Docker tales
item.description:
Having worked for many years, I’ve primarily encountered the CentOS operating system. If you are a Mac or Ubuntu user, some of this content may not be applicable.

The installation section can refer to the manual from Tsinghua University: [https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/help/docker-ce/]

Installation

Due to an unknown and mysterious force, it is recommended to use the repository addresses provided by cloud vendors for Docker installations within China. Here, Alibaba Cloud is recommended.

Set warehouse source address 

yum install yum-utils device-mapper-persistent-data lvm2 && \
sudo yum-config-manager --add-repo http://mirrors.aliyun.com/docker-ce/linux/centos/docker-ce.repo

Deploy the latest version

As a commonly used background service, Docker is recommended to be set as a startup item; the current command applies to CentOS 7

sudo yum install -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io && systemctl enable --now docker

Deploy specified version

The release of kubernetes and docker are not fully synchronized. If you need to deploy kubernetes next, please refer to the kubernetes deployment instructions and install the specified version of docker.

yum list docker-ce --showduplicates | sort -r
sudo yum install -y docker-ce-18.09.2-3.el7 docker-ce-cli-18.09.2-3.el7 containerd.io-18.09.2-3.el7 && systemctl enable --now docker

Adding Docker permissions for regular users 

sudo usermod -aG docker ${USER}

Uninstall 

sudo yum erase -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io

Everyday use

Mirror acceleration

There are still unknown mysterious forces causing slow image pulls. At this time, domestic cloud vendors have stepped up and provided many acceleration services. I still recommend Alibaba Cloud.

To obtain the accelerated address, please register for an Alibaba Cloud account yourself. This service is free, and Alibaba Cloud also provides a free image building service.

cat > /etc/docker/daemon.json <<EOF
{
  "registry-mirrors": [
    "https://docker.nju.edu.cn",
    "https://mirror.baidubce.com",
    "https://docker.m.daocloud.io",
    "https://docker.mirrors.sjtug.sjtu.edu.cn"
  ]
}
EOF
systemctl daemon-reload && \
systemctl restart docker

Highly recommended control panel 

docker volume create portainer_data && \
docker run -d --name=portainer --restart=always -p 9000:9000 -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock -v portainer_data:/data portainer/portainer-ce:2.20.3-alpine

Commonly Used Image Pull Collection 

docker pull rancher/rancher:stable && docker pull  portainer/portainer-ce:2.0.1 && \
docker pull centos:7 && docker pull ubuntu:20.04 && docker pull ubuntu:18.04 && \
docker pull redis:5 && docker pull redis:6 && \
docker pull alpine:3.11 && docker pull busybox:1.32 && \
docker pull rabbitmq:3.7-management && \
docker pull mariadb:10.2 && \
docker pull nginx:1.18 && docker pull nginx:1.19 && \
docker pull mysql:5.6 && docker pull mysql:8 && \
docker pull elasticsearch:6.8.11 && docker pull logstash:6.8.11 && docker pull kibana:6.8.11 && \
docker pull zookeeper:3.4 && \
docker pull influxdb:1.7 && docker pull grafana/grafana:7.3.1 && \
docker pull percona:8 && docker pull percona:5.6 && \
docker pull cloverzrg/frps-docker:0.34.3 && docker pull cloverzrg/frpc-docker:0.34.3

Commonly Used Command Combinations

https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/docker/

Check the container running status, add the format parameter to view detailed container information; ignore image information at this time

docker ps --format "{{.Names}}: {{.Ports}}: {{.Size}}"
#portainer: 0.0.0.0:8000->8000/tcp, 0.0.0.0:9000->9000/tcp: 0B (virtual 172MB)
#influxdb: 0.0.0.0:8086->8086/tcp: 183B (virtual 311MB)

Stop all containers with one click

docker stop $(docker ps -a -q)

Delete all images with one click

dokcer rmi $(docker images -a -q)

Export image

docker save <IMAGE NAME>:<IMAGE TAG> > -o XXX.tar

Export image and compress

docker save <IMAGE NAME>:<IMAGE TAG> | gzip > XXX.tar

Import image

docker load -i XXX.tar

item.title: Setting up a JMeter testing environment on Linux
item.description:
The author has a strong interest in hardware and used JMeter to conduct stress testing, documenting the process of deploying JMeter, InfluxDB, and Grafana on CentOS 7. They shared information on JMeter installation and command usage, InfluxDB features and Docker installation methods, as well as simple deployment and configuration of Grafana. The document summarizes experiences and references for high-performance programming patterns.

Background

As you all know, I have a strong interest in hardware. By chance, the testing team was using JMeter for performance testing and found that the performance wasn’t improving. As a curious person, I decided to jump in and see how our company does pressure testing. Thereâ€™s also a little story here: at some point in the distant past, I saw a post on Open Source China about how to create high-end performance test charts. The testers have already seen the Windows version execute tests and achieve visualized TPS data display. What use would there be for configuring another web panel?

Whatever you think is right, you won’t understand until you try it yourself Don’t use GUI mode for load testing! only for Test creation and Test debuggin.

The official recommendation is to obtain the load test report through the command line and display it with a GUI, which may introduce data errors? I don’t have a very deep understanding of JMeter, but at least it gives me a reason to tinker with the Linux console panel

The posts on Open Source China indicate that the deployment method for the core components is not user-friendly, and you need to follow a public account to download the required files. As a young generation, of course, I replaced it with Docker. To put it simply, the servers are still located within mainland China, so accessing cross-border sources is very slow. At least for image services, Alibaba Cloud has a free accelerator.

Regarding the installation and deployment of docker, details will not be repeated here; please refer to previous articles for more information

The following content is divided into two main parts: building the basic test environment components and a simple explanation of each component

Jmeter

Apache JMeter is a load testing tool developed by the Apache organization based on Java. It is used for stress testing software and was originally designed for web application testing, but has since been extended to other testing areas. It can be used to test static and dynamic resources such as static files, small Java services, CGI scripts, Java objects, databases, FTP servers, etc. JMeter can simulate a huge load on servers, networks or objects to test their strength under different stress categories and analyze overall performance. In addition, JMeter can perform functional/regression testing of applications by creating scripts with assertions to verify that your program returns the expected results. For maximum flexibility, JMeter allows the use of regular expressions to create assertions.

Apache JMeter can be used to test the performance of static and dynamic resources (files, Servlets, Perl scripts, Java objects, databases and queries, FTP servers, etc.). It can be used to simulate heavy loads on servers, networks or objects to test their strength or analyze overall performance under different types of stress. You can use it for graphical analysis of performance or for load testing your servers/scripts/objects with high concurrency.

JMeter deployment on CentOS 7

Install the JDK runtime environment, download the JMeter installation package

yum install java-1.8.0-openjdk -y && \
wget https://mirrors.bfsu.edu.cn/apache//jmeter/binaries/apache-jmeter-5.4.tgz && tar -xf apache-jmeter-5.4.tgz

Configure environment variables

export JMETER_HOME=$HOME/jmeter/apache-jmeter-5.4
export PATH=$JMETER_HOME/bin:$PATH

JMeter commands

Finally, it will connect to the Grafana control panel. You can omit the -l parameter and observe the data in the web console.

jmeter -n -t /tmp/order-500-10s.jmx -l /tmp/jmeter-order-report-20200109/order-500-10s.jtl
# ä¸€èˆ¬ä¸ç”¨æµ‹è¯•ç»“æœå’Œæµ‹è¯•æŠ¥å‘Šï¼Œç®€åŒ–å‘½ä»¤
jmeter -n -t /tmp/order-500-10s.jmx

InfluxDB

InfluxDB is an open-source distributed time series, event and metrics database written in Go, requiring no external dependencies. This database is now primarily used to store large volumes of timestamped data, such as DevOps monitoring data, APP metrics, IoT sensor data, and real-time analytics data.

InfluxDB Features

The characteristics of InfluxDB can be summarized into 9 aspects:

  • Unstructured (patternless): can be any number of columns;
  • The retention period for metrics can be configured
  • Supports time-related functions (such as min, max, sum, count, mean, median, etc.) for statistical analysis
  • Support for storage policies: can be used for data deletion and modification. (InfluxDB does not provide methods for deleting or modifying data.)
  • Supporting continuous queries: a set of statements that are automatically started on a schedule in the database, and when paired with storage policies, can reduce InfluxDB’s system footprint
  • Native HTTP support, built-in HTTP API
  • Supports SQL-like syntax
  • Supports setting the number of data replicas in the cluster
  • Support periodic sampling data and write it to another measurement for granular storage of data

InfluxDB Docker installation 

mkdir influxdb && cd influxdb && \
docker run -p 8086:8086 -d --name influxdb -v $PWD:/var/lib/influxdb influxdb:1.7

Enter the container, execute a command, and manually create a database

root@bce0a55bbc72:/# influx
Connected to http://localhost:8086 version 1.7.10
InfluxDB shell version: 1.7.10
> äº¤äº’é¢æ¿æ‰§è¡Œå‘½ä»¤

Creating Databases and Users in InfluxDB

Create database: create database jmeter_t2 View databases Switch database: use jmeter_t2 Create user “admin” with password ‘admin’ with all privileges View users

> show users
user  admin
----  -----
admin true

If the user permission admin is displayed as true, the database preparation is complete

Grafana

When writing test cases, I realized that the chart display isn’t really necessary. The tps data for the interface can already be observed when executed in the command line; mostly, I just want to know the internal execution time of the program.

Quickly deploy a Grafana dashboard, import configuration files, and connect to InfluxDB

The console supports filtering test results by tag, and generally only an InfluxDB database needs to be configured

  • Application Name
  • Test Case Name

docker run -d --name=grafana -p 3000:3000 grafana/grafana:7.3.1

The TPS and related values calculated in the web version can be inconsistent with the aggregated report in JMeter due to the sampler interval, see reference link: https://www.vinsguru.com/jmeter-real-time-results-influxdb-grafana/

The document also describes how to customize listeners

Afterword

  • High-performance programming inherently relies on a single loop thread; any locks, queuing for entry, and queuing for exit will cause unnecessary performance loss
  • The time spent on core business logic is greater than the time spent introducing other code; concurrency can effectively improve efficiency, and if the core processing time is sufficiently small, it’s best to be cautious when introducing other code

Reference materials

  • Real-time Monitoring with JMeter + Grafana + InfluxDB
  • InfluxDB official image
  • Grafana official image
  • Apache JMeter Official Website
  • To install Apache JMeter in CentOS7

item.title: Red Hat and CentOS lifecycles
item.description:
Online production environments typically use Red Hat and CentOS as their operating systems. Links to the official websites documenting the lifecycles of these two systems are provided, along with shared experiences upgrading from CentOS 8 to CentOS 8 Stream.

Preface

In online production environments, Red Hat and CentOS are currently the mainstream choices in China. Following the retirement of Red Hat 6 in recent years, here are links to the official websites for the lifecycles of these two systems.

Main body

  • Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle
  • CentOS Product Specification

Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) and CentOS are popular choices for enterprise-grade server operating systems. RHEL offers a stable support and update cycle, suitable for enterprise applications. CentOS, as the community version of RHEL, provides similar functionality and stability but lacks official support.

Chase for more

When I published this article, I never thought I would update it two years later. Just the other day, I upgraded my daily-use virtual machine from CentOS 8 to CentOS 8 Stream. I won’t say much about how to choose for production environments, but I still prefer the latest versions for local environments.

CentOS 8 Stream is a rolling release version that offers faster updates and new features compared to traditional CentOS, making it suitable for development and testing environments

item.title: US-China trade war
item.description:
Let’s start with a tangent, the differences between socialism with Chinese characteristics and capitalism. From the older generation, Iâ€™ve heard that to get rich, you must first build roads. Infrastructure construction in China is funded by the state; in a capitalist society, these would be contracted out. In remote areas, there are no profits to be made, so companies wouldn’t be willing to take on the work. Talking too much will stray from the current articleâ€™s theme. Ordinary people may feel that the trade war has little impact on their lives, but in reality, Chinaâ€™s high-end manufacturing has always been relatively weak. In the IT industry I work in, memory, hard drives, CPUs, and graphics cards â€“ the core components of assembling a computer â€“ all come from foreign factories. The cost of these parts accounts for 50% of the total price of the machine. High-end manufacturing is imperative. The collision between China and the United States is inevitable.

Reference materials

  • The Sino-American trade war that began in 2018
  • Made in China 2025

Wikipedia

The Sino-American trade war, also known as the Chinaâ€“United States trade war, or more briefly as the Sino-US trade dispute, Sino-US trade friction, Sino-US trade quarrel, or US-China trade war, is a trade war between the People’s Republic of China and the United States of America

The trade dispute originated when U.S. President Donald Trump signed a memorandum on March 22, 2018, claiming that “China steals American intellectual property and business secrets,” and directed the United States Trade Representative to impose tariffs on goods imported from China under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, involving an estimated total value of $60 billion. On July 6, 2018, the U.S. imposed a 25% additional tariff on Chinese exports worth $340 billion. The Ministry of Commerce of China responded with retaliatory measures on the same day, imposing a 25% additional tariff on U.S. exports to China worth $340 billion, including soybeans, one of the most exported products from the United States to China.

The US and China had previously reached a consensus in May 2018 to suspend the trade war and issued a joint statement seeking resolution. However, the Office of the United States Trade Representative subsequently announced on June 16th a first batch of tariffs targeting $500 billion worth of Chinese goods entering the US, raising the original 10% tariff rate to 25%. In response, the State Council Tariff Commission of China retaliated with equivalent measures, and the Ministry of Commerce also resumed anti-dumping investigations on multiple US products. On July 6th, the Trump administration formally imposed a 25% tariff on $340 billion worth of Chinese goods in the first batch of tariffs, marking the formal implementation of Trump’s China tariff policy (the remaining $160 billion was subsequently subject to a 25% tariff on August 23rd). The Ministry of Commerce later stated in a statement that “The United States violated WTO rules and launched the largest trade war in economic history.” Customs authorities said that Chinaâ€™s countermeasures had been implemented immediately after the US tariffs took effect.

On December 1, at the G20 summit in Buenos Aires, leaders Xi Jinping and Donald Trump reached a consensus to conduct 90-day negotiations and suspend new trade measures during the negotiation period. After the deadline of March 1, 2019, the United States announced significant progress and extended the suspension of new trade measures.

On May 5, 2019, U.S. President Donald Trump announced tariffs of 25% on Chinese goods entering the United States valued at approximately $200 billion, bringing the total subject to tariffs to $250 billion. The measure took effect on June 1 for Chinese products arriving at U.S. ports. On May 13, the State Council Tariff Commission of China announced that it would raise tariffs by 5% to 25% on certain imports from the United States valued at $60 billion, effective June 1. On June 1, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative announced a postponement of the U.S. tariff increase to June 15, while the State Council Tariff Commission of China stated that Chinaâ€™s retaliatory tariffs would take effect as scheduled on June 1.

On June 29, the leaders of the two countries, Xi Jinping and Donald Trump, held talks at the G20 Osaka Summit, agreeing to restart trade consultations and for the United States not to impose new tariffs on Chinese products

On August 1, due to the Trump administration’s dissatisfaction with the progress of Chinaâ€™s purchases of U.S. agricultural products, Trump announced on Twitter that starting September 1, 2019, a 10% tariff would be imposed on all remaining Chinese goods exported to the United States valued at $300 billion. On August 5, the exchange rate of the renminbi against the U.S. dollar fell below the 7 threshold. On the same day, the U.S. Treasury Department announced that it was designating China as a currency manipulator. Subsequently, the Chinese government announced a suspension of purchases of U.S. agricultural products and on August 24 announced tariffs of 10% or 5% on approximately $750 billion worth of U.S. goods, and resumed tariffs on U.S. automobiles and their parts; in response, the United States increased the tariff rate previously imposed on $300 billion worth of Chinese goods to 15%, and raised the current 25% tariff on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods to 30%, but this was later put on hold.

On January 16, 2020, China and the United States signed the Phase One trade agreement

item.title: Building computers
item.description:
The author was fascinated by assembling computers from a young age and began learning about hardware assembly after starting university. They recommended websites for comparing hardware performance and provided purchasing suggestions, including CPU, solid-state drives, mechanical hard drives, and memory frequency. They also shared their experience and precautions regarding hardware selection.

Destiny, beyond words

Ever since I was little, I wanted to build my own computer, but the economic conditions just wouldn’t allow it. It wasnâ€™t until college that I finally had the chance, and for portability reasons, I got a laptop. If you want a specific time frame, when did I start wanting to build a computer? It all started at the library back home. It was a pretty decent-sized library for a city district â€“ it had an electronic reading room (though I never went, as it charged by the hour) and a magazine reading room. Thatâ€™s where I stumbled upon magazines like â€œå¤§ä¼—è½¯ä»¶â€ (Popular Software) and â€œç”µè„‘æŠ¥â€ (Computer News). For someone with limited exposure to computers, they were essentially divine educational resources. Seeing chapters about raiding dungeons made me want to build my own computer so I could pull mobs and be a main damage dealer; seeing the “black technology” sparked fantasies of recreating what was described in the books (a discussion on using hacking tools). Though high school coursework was demanding, with my limited knowledge at the time, I felt I needed to both study and play. It was a pretty carefree time. Iâ€™d often use going to the library as an excuse, grabbing a small bag and strolling over there. The city wasn’t that big, so I usually walked. Once inside, Iâ€™d enjoy the air conditioning while reading novels, comics, and gaming magazines, occasionally glancing at some serious books.

As you get older, it’s easy to forget things. This isn’t the first time something like this has happened at the library. When I was in junior high school, my relatives assembled a computer, and I donâ€™t remember why they built that machine back then. The operating system was Windows 2003, and the games included the card game and Age of Empires. I spent all sorts of time trying to sneak the keys and play games with my cousin.

Entering junior high, the school offered basic computer training. Later, when I transferred schools, I was also introduced to the concept of computer competitions. By the time I reached high school, I participated in NOIP once. Speaking of this, it’s impossible not to mention the power of alumni â€“ the high schoolâ€™s computer building was funded by alumni donations and included a computer lab and library. It was actually during the initial wave of China’s internet boom at that time. School leaders also supported participation in computer competitions; after all, several seniors from the previous two years had been admitted to key universities through computer-related programs.

I’ve never looked back at my relationship with computers like this before. No wonder I made such a complete shift from the automation major to the computer industry after graduation â€“ the seeds were already sown, though those involved didnâ€™t realize it. Having been exposed to them since childhood, I thought I was quite knowledgeable, but in reality, I only understood the basics. My biggest advantage was that initial passion.

Hardware assembly

Browse Carrefour, Chiphell, and Zhihu’s computer building sections; a beginner can relatively easily create a list of the machine they need. When purchasing a CPU after 2019, if your financial situation isnâ€™t abundant, AMD is the best choice for higher performance.

Here’s a translation of the provided Chinese text: I recommend a commonly used hardware performance comparison website: https://cpu.userbenchmark.com/, which is comparable to Xianyu (é—²é±¼) for pricing. True experts can find great deals on used items on Xianyu, saving a lot of money. If you’re not very knowledgeable, I donâ€™t recommend using it; I bought fake memory there myself. Although it seems to be working fine so far, Iâ€™m not entirely sure, and the model and parameters are completely mismatched.

SN550 VS SN750

The difference between the SN550 1TB and the SN750 1TB is that their sustained read/write speeds differ by a factor of two â€“ one reaches 850MB, the other 1.6GB. However, there’s no noticeable difference in daily use because both have the same 4K performance. Of course, this refers to the 1TB capacity SN550; the 500GB and 250GB versions have slower sequential read/write speeds. Honestly, unless youâ€™re not worried about cost, the SN550 is fine for everyday use. The main reason I didn’t buy it isn’t its sequential read/write speed, but rather that it only comes in a maximum of 1TB capacity, while the SN750 offers 2TB. For me, the value lies more in having an extra M.2 NVMe slot on my motherboard than in the price difference between these SSDs, without needing to expand further.

Based on the consensus of online users, purchasing an adapter board will allow a B150 motherboard to support an M.2 SSD

Choosing a Mechanical Hard Drive

Currently, mechanical hard drives are priced stably. For users with large storage needs, it is recommended to select a suitable mechanical hard drive. Frequent downloaders are advised to consider enterprise-grade hard drives, such as:

  • Western Digital Gold
  • Seagate Exos

It’s recommended to partition large-capacity mechanical hard drives. Frequent download operations should be directed to a specific partition. If bad sectors appear later, they can be concentrated in one partition, and that partition can then be discarded, effectively extending the lifespan of the mechanical hard drive.

Seagate Official Introduction

Overview of Seagate Enterprise Hard Drives

Overview of Seagate Enterprise Hard Drives

Memory frequency

Starting from the perspective of daily work, frequency will not have a significant impact on performance

Memory Timing Memory (Salted Fish Memory)

Memory timings (or RAM timings) are four parameters describing the performance of synchronous dynamic random-access memory (SDRAM): CL, TRCD, TRP, and TRAS, measured in clock cycles. They are typically written as four numbers separated by hyphens, such as 7-8-8-24. The fourth parameter (RAS) is often omitted, and a fifth parameter may be added: Command rate, usually 2T or 1T, also written as 2N or 1N. These parameters specify latency times that affect random access memory speed. Lower numbers generally indicate faster performance. The ultimate element determining system performance is the actual latency time, typically measured in nanoseconds.

When converting memory timings to actual delays, it’s most important to note that they are measured in clock cycles. Without knowing the duration of a clock cycle, itâ€™s impossible to determine if one set of numbers is faster than another.

For example, the clock frequency of DDR3-2000 memory is 1000 MHz, and its clock cycle is 1 ns. Based on this 1 ns clock, a CL=7 results in an absolute latency of 7 ns. Faster DDR3-2666 (clocking at 1333 MHz with a 0.75 ns cycle) may use a larger CL=9, but still produce a shorter absolute latency of 6.75 ns.

Modern DIMMs include a serial presence detect (SPD) ROM chip, which contains memory timings recommended for automatic configuration. The PC’s BIOS may allow users to adjust these timings to improve performance (with the risk of reducing stability), or in some cases increase stability (such as using the recommended timings).

Note: Memory bandwidth measures memory throughput and is typically limited by transfer rate rather than latency. It is possible to continuously transmit at peak rates by interleaving access to multiple internal banks of SDRAM. Bandwidth can be increased at the expense of increased latency. Specifically, each new generation of DDR memory has a higher transfer rate, but absolute latency does not change significantly, especially for the first batch of products in a new generation, which often have longer latencies than the previous generation.

Even with increased memory latency, increasing memory bandwidth can improve the performance of computer systems with multiple processors or multiple execution threads. Higher bandwidth will also enhance the performance of integrated graphics cards without dedicated video memory.

Memory Timing Parameter Explanation

Reference materials
